author: deepinterwebz
body:
Buy AZUL airlines

I bought 2650 shares at $6.71 few weeks back. Up almost 100%. Still a huge amount of upside imo. Airline stocks in general will begin moving up quickly imo. Extremely undervalued after the Coronavirus fears. I think people are seeing their value and this buying opportunity wont last long. AZUL share price tripled from roughly $15 to $45 over last 2 years before Coronavirus struck. Extremely cheap to get into a company with a solid management team.

Technical Analysis. The price just crossed back over the 50 Moving Average the other day with a Golden Cross as the 10 MA crossed over the 50 MA the other day. Volume has been insane. Last month was the highest volume in AZUL history. The RSI just passed back over the 50 line by a large margin on the daily chart, first time since before Coronavirus. Also, the end of week close closed at almost the high of week, a good sign this bull run will continue. Brazilian airlines are about a month behind US airlines with Coronavirus so expect this one to do the same as all the US airlines have already done in price.  The future of AZUL is looking bright.

author: Xayo
body:
It's delusional to think that Visa and MasterCard will see adoption in China. Even if they get official approval, the government and general population will still be very much against foreign payment providers. Whchat, alipay and UnionPay already offer a well established, widely adopted, and arguably superior homegrown alternative. There is nothing to be gained by Chinese companies and people to adopt visa/MasterCard. It will simply be a more expensive and more beurocratic alternative, that you can't even use as no small business owner will go through the trouble of setting it up. Even for traveling abroad it will be useless, as most tourist destinations in Europe and Asia already accept the Chinese payment services just like they do American ones.

Otherwise I fully agree with your post.

Plus maybe wait a few weeks before starting. That being said most companies seem good what you choose above . I don’t know what kinda risk you want to take but Tesla is very volatile . Plus buying amazon and  Tesla means you won’t have much left to invest and diversify your portfolio. That means you will be tied down to few shares. There are many other companies that are trading lower and it will take them time to rebound. Like Boeing, Pepsi and coca cola also solid companies not crazy growth ahead but they are stable companies. Microsoft is another good one with visa and MasterCard. Hope that helps. Always do your own research also.

author: Tristanna
body:
I did, this is the result. Bitcoin as currency solves no problems that people who spend money have with the exception being illegal transactions. Bitcoin does a great job at protecting those transactions which will mean it always has some value. Bitcoin does not offer any advantages to the consumer over Visa or Mastercard and their networks for dollar transactions and in fact offers a worse user experience due to its extreme volatility and the lack of confidence a user by extension has in its day to day value. Contrast that with the USD or Euro and the confidence you have that tomorrow 2 bucks still gets you a pound of chicken. 

If you cannot defend your position on bitcoin, you should reconsider it.

author: 1monster90
body:
You shouldn't invest money you can't afford to lose. Personally, money in the stock market is money I am considering nonexistent until 2045.   
Don't be greedy but don't be cynical either. I think you could really benefit from making a list of interesting stocks. And from that list try to pick at least 10 stocks that you find promising and buy. Even if it's just 1 share (that way you will be focused on these companies, it's not so much to make a profit than making yourself focus and research these companies. I find it easier to focus on stocks I have at least one share with that stocks I don't own at all).  


Here is my list of shares I'm watching carefully, feel free to research it.  
MSFT, V, MA, NKE, NTDOY, LOGI, SPXL, TQQQ, DOCU,  TRIP, ALGN, F, GME, APPL, NFLX, SBUX, LUV, HS, AMZN, AAL, TMUS, PG,  INTC, QCOM, PYPL, T, ATVI, RSG, FDM, AXP, CSCO, TGT, PLSE, TROW, ORCL,  FDX, CUBE, BABA, CTAS, ALK, JNJ, LLY, CB, NEE, FANG, GAMR, TWLO, TNA,  LABU, FAS, CTRE, PEP, EBAY, DFS, GE, SNQP, MS, RF, AMG, HIG, BR, BEN,  ZNGA, COR, WWE, WYNN, VT, VTI, ELY, ADBE, SQ, TWTR, CVS, CRSP, QQ, NDLS,  WU, MTRX, PUTW, TECL, GM, NYMT, MU and NDAQ .

author: Legitimate-Assistant
body:
This would be a misconception.

Visa and Mastercard do still profit yes, but Square is a gateway+merchant acquirer type of package. Typically all merchants using Square will be using the specific processor and merchant acquirer that is Squares. This means, the fees charged to merchants for transaction processing will be going to Square, who then will pay Visa their share.

The whole system is broken to separate pieces where everyone gets a share.

There are gateways, which let people submit transactions to processors.There are processors, who process the transactions and communicate between gateways, merchant acquirers, and the card holders card issuing bank.

There are merchant acquirers who basically act as the bank for the merchant is primarily the one liable for funding transactions to the merchant, and receiving incoming funds from transactions. The Merchant Acquirer and the Card Issuing banks are where the money is actually moving.

The card issuing bank is Chase, or your credit union, whatever bank actually issued the credit/debit card in use.

And there are the card network providers, Visa, Amex etc.. who get money because all of it is running on their services.

And in this mix and match are some companies that do one or all parts of the roles.  


  
Long story short, all of financial digital services get their cut, and really they are all fighting to see who gets the most customers to have the biggest cut. Like every other business. But Visa, Mastercard, Amex, are not quite the same as Square, Paypal, etc... As currently all credit and debit card services operate off of the card services network infrastructure that those companies have implemented.

body: MasterCard

author: InfiniteValueptr
body:
Where is your figure of Mastercard's 40% operating margin from? From their 10-K, 2019 operating margins were 57.3%, while Visa's was 67.2% - so it's a 10% difference, not 20%.

As for why, that can largely be attributed to scale. Mastercard is 3/4 the size of Visa, and operating expenses for payment processing are relatively fixed, so the more scale you get the higher margins.

author: residentdoc
body:
Not sure what you are asking. 

1. If you are asking how much stocks of an individual company you should buy: I'd recommend buying 100 at a time, this way you can do options. if you can't afford 100 at a time, no worries, buy however much you like.
2. If you are asking how diversified you should go in terms of how many companies to invest in: I'd say invest in however many companies you want to. Hard to say exactly how many is good, but it's a good rule to try to diversify into multiple different industries. For example, don't put all your money into bank of america, wells fargo, jp morgan, citi, visa, mastercard, and american express. Try to diversify into technology (MSFT, NVDA, intel, AMD, etc), energy (COP, etc), and other stocks you just like.

Have fun above all: trading stocks can get stressful

author: Limbo3i3
body: These help to monitor direction. If the price hits top BB then it’ll most likely move back towards the MA and possibly below it towards the bottom BB. It’s a rinse and repeat process. Look at the 5min candle sticks and just look at the movement overtime. You see a pattern. But if you want to try and predict where to throw your nut sack on the table then look at the overall flow of the chart and guess which direction you think it’ll go. Think of this shit like a ping pong ball. Bounce the fucker and watch it go up and down. GLHF.
